Spoliers Inside - a film review needs hidden spoilers like this post

Director Roland Suso Richter‚Äôs enigmatic psychological thriller (direct to video/DVD) was based upon screenwriter Michael Cooney‚Äôs own play ‚ÄúPoint of Death‚Äù - a title that gave away the film‚Äôs entire plot twist premise.

As in many similar films, such as Jacob‚Äôs Ladder (1990), Soul Survivors (2001), and The Butterfly Effect (2004), events and people were thoroughly distorted and confused because the protagonist was at the point of death. The tagline was misleading:

‚ÄúWhen You Don‚Äôt Have a Memory, How Can You Remember Who to Trust?‚Äù

The mind-warping film opened with a hospital patient Simon Cable (Ryan Phillippe) awakening in a hospital with little knowledge (amnesia perhaps?) of what had happened, and why he was there, etc. He was told by attending Dr. Jeremy Newman (Stephen Rea) that it was July 29, 2002 (Simon thought it was the year 2000 - he was confused - he heard a doctor say 20:00 hours!) and that he had died for two minutes from cardiac arrest following the near-fatal accident ‚Äì but he had been revived (‚ÄúYou‚Äôre as good as new‚Äù). Dr. Newman: ‚ÄúSimon, this is the 29th of July. The year is 2002. And your wife, whose name is Anna, is waiting outside.‚Äù

What critiques say?

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs almost no single moment in Portrait of a Lady on Fire that couldn‚Äôt be captured, mounted, and hung on a wall as high art.‚Äù ‚Äî Entertainment Weekly

A major clue to everything that truly happened was the scene that played next under the credits - hospital staff failed to bring a patient back to life with a defibrillator after a car accident. Chest compressions failed and there was no pulse. A second major clue was provided by hospital orderly Travis (Stephen Graham): Everybody dies. No mystery there. But why and how everyone dies. Now, there‚Äôs a mystery worth solving. Probably the biggest mystery there is.

So how do we add spoilers in this theme?
